section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about the letters Oo and Pp, engage children with a movement activity, and introduce vocabulary (giant).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, Why does Eddie go into the woods?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach the letters Oo and Pp.
Read On the Box and Paint.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are there any bears in the book you are reading? Who is in your book?
Pretend you are Eddie and look for your lost bear.
Show me a counter for the bear, for Freddie and for big Ted. How many counters do you have?
What is the biggest thing you’ve ever seen? Can you write about it and draw a picture?
How can you use the materials to make a giant teddy for the bear?
Draw an O and a P in the sand tray.
How can you build a bed for Eddie and his teddy? Is it the right size?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the talk about your feelings Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary (change, imagine).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Where’s My Teddy?
Read closely to notice and talk about feelings and emotions.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Identify emotions in self; Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Invite children to make a bear puppet.
Encourage children to use the bear puppets to express the bear’s feelings.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do you feel when you read a book you like?
Can you act out what Eddie does at the end of the story? How does he feel?
Find two objects. Which one is big? Which one is small?
Can you make a picture of your favorite stuffed animal and write about it?
Can you make something to make a giant bear happy?
Can you make the letters Oo and Pp with play clay?
How can you build a bed for the bear and his teddy? Is it the right size?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a chant, and introduce vocabulary (stomping).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Where’s My Teddy? and asking, How are Eddie and the gigantic bear alike?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long.”

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach children how to measure using Connecting Cubes.
Encourage children to compare and determine how big or how little.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose two books. Which is bigger? Which is heavier?
Pretend you are a gigantic bear. How do you feel?
Can you draw trees in the woods? Make one tree big and one tree little.
Can you draw a teddy and label it Freddie?
How can you make your own bear using the things you see here?
What word begins like penguin and peach? What word begins like ostrich and octopus?
How can you build a giant bear using blocks?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Where’s My Teddy? by Jez Alborough. Copyright © 1992 by Jez Alborough. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: I Can Measure

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about ways to measure, engage children with a heavy or light activity, and introduce vocabulary (heavy, light).
Begin Story Time by connecting Where’s My Teddy? and I Can Measure.
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Use information to compare and contrast.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).

section-block.tg_skills-focus_body: Measurement: Use formal or informal measurement tools (e.g., balance scale, cups, blocks, paper clips, etc.) to observe and describe weight, length, and volume; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.”

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to explore the concept of heavy versus light using a simple scale (balance or digital).
Ask children to predict before measuring.
Differentiate and modify as needed

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Choose a book. Hold a tissue in one hand and the book in the other. Which is heavier?
Can you put the following items in order, from smallest to largest—plate and cups?
Pick two things. Can you use a balance scale to figure out which thing weighs more?
Can you draw a penguin and a whale, and tell which is lighter?
Can you make three bears in different sizes, and then put them in size order?
How can you put the letter tiles (from A to P) in ABC order? Sing “The Alphabet Song” to help you!
Can you build a house for the big teddy bear?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Where’s My Teddy? by Jez Alborough. Copyright © 1992 by Jez Alborough. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out a scene from the story and to review the week’s vocabulary (huddle and cuddle).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, Why wouldn’t you take the giant teddy home?
Read and retell interactively.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat the details in a text.
Recognize at least 20 letter sounds.
Write with some letter-sound correspondence writing.
Identify emotions in self.
Understand and use a growing number of question words (who, what, where, when, why, how).
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: If you could build your own teddy, how would you make it?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do we measure how big, how much, or how many?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you pretend to read to your teddy? What story would you choose?
Imagine that you are building a house. Can you pretend to measure the size of the walls, floor, and windows for the house?
Imagine you are the giant bear. How big of a step can you take? Can you work with a friend to measure the step?
Can you draw a picture of Eddie and Freddie?
Can you create a house for Freddie using the materials?
Can you make up a name for the bear’s bear? What letter does it begin with?
Which blocks would you use to make a giant bear?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books to describe, relate, categorize, or compare and contrast.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Use information learned from books to describe, relate, categorize, or compare and contrast.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Move from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondence using beginning and ending sounds when writing.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
Use information learned from books to describe, relate, categorize, or compare and contrast.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Move from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondence using beginning and ending sounds when writing.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Use information learned from books to describe, relate, categorize, or compare and contrast.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Move from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondence using beginning and ending sounds when writing.
Manage transitions and adapt to change in activities or situations.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects
Informally recognize and compare weights of objects or people.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Recognize at least 20 distinct letter sounds in the language of instruction.
Move from scribbles to some letter-sound correspondence using beginning and ending sounds when writing.
Begin to understand difference and connection between emotions/feelings and behaviors.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
